articles.headline: Assignment America: Sandpoint, Idaho
articles.snippet: Through grit and persistence, the center is holding in this Western small town, against forces that are turning other hamlets into ghost towns.
articles.abstract: Through grit and persistence, the center is holding in this Western small town, against forces that are turning other hamlets into ghost towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Articles in this series are exploring changes in American politics, culture and technology, drawing on the reporting and personal experiences of New York Times journalists around the country.

articles.headline: It’s Summer, but Where Are the Teenage Workers?
articles.snippet: Pressed for time, competing against adults or simply not finding opportunity, fewer teenagers are in the summer work force, statistics show.
articles.abstract: Pressed for time, competing against adults or simply not finding opportunity, fewer teenagers are in the summer work force, statistics show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ice cream still needs scooping, beaches still need guarding and campers still need counseling. But now, there are way fewer teenagers doing it all this summer.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Logistics and Lizards Disrupt Chevron’s Project Off Australia
articles.snippet: Remoteness and environmental concerns piled costs on the Gorgon liquefied natural gas project, just as energy prices slumped.
articles.abstract: Remoteness and environmental concerns piled costs on the Gorgon liquefied natural gas project, just as energy prices slumped.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Getting anything to Chevron’s gas-processing plant on Barrow Island is a bit of a trick.

articles.headline: Health Insurance Companies Seek Big Rate Increases for 2016
articles.snippet: The companies say new customers under the Affordable Care Act have been sicker than expected, while federal officials say they want the requests scaled back.
articles.abstract: The companies say new customers under the Affordable Care Act have been sicker than expected, while federal officials say they want the requests scaled back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Health insurance companies around the country are seeking rate increases of 20 percent to 40 percent or more, saying their new customers under the Affordable Care Act turned out to be sicker than expected. Federal officials say they are determined to see that the requests are scaled back.

articles.headline: Despair and Anger as Puerto Ricans Cope With Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: As the commonwealth grapples with a $73 billion debt it calls unpayable, residents are dealing with higher sales tax and bracing for revenue-increasing cuts.
articles.abstract: As the commonwealth grapples with a $73 billion debt it calls unpayable, residents are dealing with higher sales tax and bracing for revenue-increasing cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — It’s the lunch hour at Baker’s Bakery, a fixture in Río Piedras, one of Puerto Rico’s oldest neighborhoods, but the bustle at the counter is long gone. The front door opens and shuts only a few times an hour as customers, holding tighter than ever to their money, judiciously pick up some sugar-sprinkled pastries and a café con leche.

articles.headline: How Iceland Emerged From Its Deep Freeze
articles.snippet: Unemployment is 4 percent, the International Monetary Fund is predicting 4.1 percent G.D.P. growth for 2015, and tourism is booming.
articles.abstract: Unemployment is 4 percent, the International Monetary Fund is predicting 4.1 percent G.D.P. growth for 2015, and tourism is booming.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the financial crisis hit Iceland seven years ago, Gudmundur Kristjansson, a 55-year-old fisherman with a wide smile, weathered face and mischievous eyes, almost lost his business. Interest payments on his loans soared 300 percent. He had to sell his two fish factories and two of his five fishing boats. “We didn’t invest for many years,” he said, “because we were only paying interest.”

articles.headline: Farm Labor Groups Make Progress on Wages and Working Conditions
articles.snippet: Innovative movements to improve what farm laborers earn, how they work and where they live are starting to have success across the country, despite numerous obstacles.
articles.abstract: Innovative movements to improve what farm laborers earn, how they work and where they live are starting to have success across the country, despite numerous obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — It was an unlikely place for a labor protest: 120 migrant workers, students and clergy members were shouting outside the flagship store of Ben & Jerry’s, which displayed a “Peace, Love and Ice Cream” sign on its facade.

articles.headline: Universal’s Back Lot Tour Adds a Bigger Dose of Movie Fantasy
articles.snippet: With actual production largely done in other locations, Universal Studios Hollywood is turning to tours that recreate the action in hit movies.
articles.abstract: With actual production largely done in other locations, Universal Studios Hollywood is turning to tours that recreate the action in hit movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — When Universal Studios opened its back lot to tourists in 1964, it was one of Hollywood’s biggest wows. For the first time, swarms of everyday people, riding in candy-striped GlamorTrams, could come face to face with filmmaking.

articles.headline: Mindful of Greece, Ukraine Is in a Rush to Line Up Debt Relief
articles.snippet: In a bid to avoid continuous negotiations with creditors, the Ukrainian government (with the I.M.F.’s support) is deep in debt talks, pressing investors to accept a bailout deal — but investors are resistant.
articles.abstract: In a bid to avoid continuous negotiations with creditors, the Ukrainian government (with the I.M.F.’s support) is deep in debt talks, pressing investors to accept a bailout deal — but investors are resistant.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Nobody knows how the endless dispute will play out between Athens and the European leaders who hold its purse strings. But in Kiev, another European capital in the grip of debt talks, one thing is certain: The Ukrainian government does not want to end up like Greece, squabbling with creditors for years.

articles.headline: Obama Plans Broader Use of Clemency to Free Nonviolent Drug Offenders
articles.snippet: President Obama is expected to free dozens of nonviolent federal drug convicts, but he will barely dent prison populations that many Democrats and Republicans agree are swollen by excessive sentences.
articles.abstract: President Obama is expected to free dozens of nonviolent federal drug convicts, but he will barely dent prison populations that many Democrats and Republicans agree are swollen by excessive sentences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sometime in the next few weeks, aides expect President Obama to issue orders freeing dozens of federal prisoners locked up on nonviolent drug offenses. With the stroke of his pen, he will probably commute more sentences at one time than any president has in nearly half a century.

articles.headline: Samsung Merger Plan Called Unfair to Some Investors
articles.snippet: Some investors have criticized the Samsung C&T-Cheil merger, saying it is being struck at a price that is unfair to the C&T shareholders.
articles.abstract: Some investors have criticized the Samsung C&T-Cheil merger, saying it is being struck at a price that is unfair to the C&T shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samsung has built a name for itself among consumers around the world as a leading manufacturer of smartphones, televisions and home appliances. For investors, though, its reputation is not so stellar.

articles.headline: Pope Francis’ Visit to Latin America Will Test His Ability to Keep Catholics in the Fold
articles.snippet: The pontiff’s roots in Argentina and his championing of the poor are considered vital to stemming the decline of the church’s vast base in the region.
articles.abstract: The pontiff’s roots in Argentina and his championing of the poor are considered vital to stemming the decline of the church’s vast base in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Pope Francis has turned heads with bold stands on climate change and income inequality. He helped broker a historic thaw between the United States and Cuba. He has shaken up the stodgy brand of the Roman Catholic Church.

articles.headline: Facing a Selfie Election, Presidential Hopefuls Grin and Bear It
articles.snippet: Who wants their babies kissed or their yard signs autographed anymore? Presidential candidates now have no choice but to submit to smartphone-wielding crowds.
articles.abstract: Who wants their babies kissed or their yard signs autographed anymore? Presidential candidates now have no choice but to submit to smartphone-wielding crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Press that white button! This right here,” the former secretary of state instructed a technologically deficient fan in New Hampshire who was fumbling to work an iPhone camera. Her patience thinning, Hillary Rodham Clinton took matters into her own hands and jabbed the button herself. And with the sound of an electronic shutter snap, another selfie — the must-have political souvenir of 2016 — went up into the cloud for campaign posterity.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Dominican Plan to Expel Haitians Tests Close Ties
articles.snippet: Many in the Dominican Republic favor being part of a trend of tightening immigration. But for some, it means facing some difficult choices.
articles.abstract: Many in the Dominican Republic favor being part of a trend of tightening immigration. But for some, it means facing some difficult choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SABANETA, Dominican Republic — For decades, the people of Barrio Cementerio, a neighborhood divided evenly between Dominicans and Haitians, have shared a peaceful coexistence. Proximity smothered prejudice: Working side by side and raising families together helped keep tensions in check.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Sandra E. Garcia

articles.headline: In Health Law, a Boon for Diet Clinics
articles.snippet: The Affordable Care Act requires insurers to pay for nutrition and obesity screening, and some doctors see a new business opportunity.
articles.abstract: The Affordable Care Act requires insurers to pay for nutrition and obesity screening, and some doctors see a new business opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Michael Kaplan looked across his desk at a woman who had sought out his Long Island Weight Loss Institute and asked the question he often poses to new patients: “Where do you think you go wrong with food?”
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Teenager’s Jailing Brings a Call to Fix Sex Offender Registries
articles.snippet: Many people hold up the case of Zachery Anderson, who at 19 had sex with a minor who lied about her age, as a reason to rethink who’s registered.
articles.abstract: Many people hold up the case of Zachery Anderson, who at 19 had sex with a minor who lied about her age, as a reason to rethink who’s registered.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELKHART, Ind. — Until one day in December, Zachery Anderson was a typical 19-year-old in a small Midwestern city.

articles.headline: Greeks Reject Bailout Terms in Rebuff to European Leaders
articles.snippet: The Interior Ministry said that more than 60 percent of voters had said no to the deal in a vote that could redefine Greece’s place in Europe and shake the Continent’s financial stability.
articles.abstract: The Interior Ministry said that more than 60 percent of voters had said no to the deal in a vote that could redefine Greece’s place in Europe and shake the Continent’s financial stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greeks delivered a shocking rebuff to Europe’s leaders on Sunday, decisively rejecting a deal offered by the country’s creditors in a historic vote that could redefine Greece’s place in Europe and shake the Continent’s financial stability.

articles.headline: Unicorn: A Fitting Label for Its Time and Place
articles.snippet: While Silicon Valley tried to separate tech winners from losers for decades, until 2013 it had not really coined a name for the kind of start-ups the industry most treasured.
articles.abstract: While Silicon Valley tried to separate tech winners from losers for decades, until 2013 it had not really coined a name for the kind of start-ups the industry most treasured.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aileen Lee tried a few lesser terms before she hit on “unicorn.” One was “home run.” Another was “megahits.” Neither quite worked for what she was going for — an unusual, mysterious word to describe what, in the tech industry, was an unusual, mysterious phenomenon: American software companies that had achieved a valuation of at least $1 billion.

articles.headline: China’s Market Rout Is a Double Threat
articles.snippet: A failure to halt the sell-off in stocks in the last three weeks has shaken Beijing’s aura of invincibility and imperils the global economy.
articles.abstract: A failure to halt the sell-off in stocks in the last three weeks has shaken Beijing’s aura of invincibility and imperils the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For nearly three years, President Xi Jinping of China has crushed opposition by silencing and often locking up anyone who dares defy the government. But that aura of invincibility has been shaken by stock market speculators who have made a mockery of efforts to halt a steep slide in share prices.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: New, Simple ‘Buy’ Buttons Aim to Entice Mobile Shoppers
articles.snippet: Companies like Google, Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest are trying to bridge the gap between smartphone browsing and desktop purchases.
articles.abstract: Companies like Google, Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest are trying to bridge the gap between smartphone browsing and desktop purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Denise Chapman, a director at a San Diego advertising agency, is afraid to count how many hours of each day she spends on her mobile phone, browsing for clothes or gifts. But when it comes time to actually buy something, instead of using her iPhone, she fires up an aging Dell computer that sits on a desk in her family’s kitchen.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Marco Rubio Is Hardly a Hero in Cuba. He Likes That.
articles.snippet: Residents of towns that were home to the Republican senator’s parents, grandparents and great-grandparents take issue with his Cuba policy, if they are aware of him at all.
articles.abstract: Residents of towns that were home to the Republican senator’s parents, grandparents and great-grandparents take issue with his Cuba policy, if they are aware of him at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: CABAIGUÁN, Cuba — In the lush countryside and teeming city neighborhoods where Senator Marco Rubio’s family cut sugar cane, toiled in tobacco mills and scraped by to make a better life for their children, the first Cuban-American to have a plausible chance to become president of the United States is the island’s least favorite son.

articles.headline: With Merging of Insurers, Questions for Patients About Costs and Innovation
articles.snippet: As insurers grow larger, the effect on consumers depends largely on how successfully other companies, particularly those created or attracted by the Affordable Care Act, can compete.
articles.abstract: As insurers grow larger, the effect on consumers depends largely on how successfully other companies, particularly those created or attracted by the Affordable Care Act, can compete.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s five largest health insurance companies are circling one another like hungry lions closing in on prey.

articles.headline: A Migrant Mother’s Anguished Choice
articles.snippet: Lost in the diplomatic wrangling over the fate of the Rohingya fleeing Myanmar are the harrowing personal consequences.
articles.abstract: Lost in the diplomatic wrangling over the fate of the Rohingya fleeing Myanmar are the harrowing personal consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: GELUGOR, Malaysia — Carrying one child in her arm, a second on her back and holding the hand of a third, Hasinah Izhar waded waist-deep through a mangrove swamp into the Bay of Bengal, toward a fishing boat bobbing in the dusk.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: White Supremacists Extend Their Reach Through Websites
articles.snippet: A manifesto linked to Dylann Roof, the suspect in the church massacre in Charleston, S.C., has refocused attention on a shadowy movement that has become more sophisticated in the Internet age.
articles.abstract: A manifesto linked to Dylann Roof, the suspect in the church massacre in Charleston, S.C., has refocused attention on a shadowy movement that has become more sophisticated in the Internet age.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late June, as much of the nation mourned the killing of nine parishioners in a Charleston, S.C., church, The Daily Stormer, a white supremacist website, was busy posting articles on a different issue: black crime against white people. “Adolescent Ape Jailed for Murdering White Man Out of Boredom,” one headline blared.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Emphatic ‘No’ Prompts Greek Pride and Revelry
articles.snippet: Celebrating the vote to say no to more austerity measures tied to a possible new bailout, Greeks gathered in Athens’ Syntagma Square and explained their frustration.
articles.abstract: Celebrating the vote to say no to more austerity measures tied to a possible new bailout, Greeks gathered in Athens’ Syntagma Square and explained their frustration.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As news spread of the surprisingly strong victory for the no side in Sunday’s referendum on the terms of a European bailout offer, Greeks poured into Syntagma Square, which has been the site of many historic political demonstrations.

articles.headline: With ‘Terminator Genisys,’ David Ellison Stops Playing It Safe
articles.snippet: The son of Larry Ellison, founder of Oracle, shifts from investing in films to steering them creatively, with ‘Genisys’ and the coming addition to the ‘Mission: Impossible’ franchise.
articles.abstract: The son of Larry Ellison, founder of Oracle, shifts from investing in films to steering them creatively, with ‘Genisys’ and the coming addition to the ‘Mission: Impossible’ franchise.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — David Ellison, the 32-year-old son of Larry Ellison, the billionaire Oracle founder, sat in a temporary office here in early June and offered his take on Hollywood — lessons learned from five years of producing big-budget movies like his “Terminator Genisys,” which was then just a few weeks from opening.

articles.headline: Rift Emerges as Europe Gears Up for New Talks on Greece Bailout
articles.snippet: Germany continued to maintain a hard line with Athens on Monday, but some European countries showed a willingness to soften the push for austerity.
articles.abstract: Germany continued to maintain a hard line with Athens on Monday, but some European countries showed a willingness to soften the push for austerity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Germany continued to maintain a hard line with Athens on Monday, just a day after Greek voters decisively rejected a bailout deal from its creditors. But some European countries showed a willingness to soften the push for austerity that has proved so contentious.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Free Hotel Wi-Fi Is Increasingly on Travelers’ Must-Have List
articles.snippet: Hotel guests, used to receiving free Wi-Fi nearly everywhere, are becoming less willing to pay the fees high-end flagship hotels charge for the service.
articles.abstract: Hotel guests, used to receiving free Wi-Fi nearly everywhere, are becoming less willing to pay the fees high-end flagship hotels charge for the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travelers sometimes compare Wi-Fi to hot water, electricity or air — and when wireless access at a hotel shows up as a line item on their bill, they tend to make a few other comparisons as well.

articles.headline: Conviction of Former Goldman Sachs Programmer Is Overturned
articles.snippet: The ruling sets the stage for state prosecutors to either appeal the decision or let Sergey Aleynikov’s six-year legal odyssey through the courts come to an end.
articles.abstract: The ruling sets the stage for state prosecutors to either appeal the decision or let Sergey Aleynikov’s six-year legal odyssey through the courts come to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kevin H. Marino pumped his fist in the air in celebration. Then Mr. Marino, a New Jersey lawyer with a linebacker’s build, turned to his longtime client, Sergey Aleynikov, and gave Mr. Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, a bear hug and a hearty pat on the back.
